Review_Url:
This film left me with a lot of thoughts in my mind. It is a well-known fact, that superiority of white people over black was called into question years ago. Still, history reveals that the lives of black people were full of humiliations even in the 20th century. The film tells us stories about the relationships between white families and their maids. Let me remind you of some of them.
In the middle of the 20th century, equal opportunities were more of a dream for negro. Just to give you an idea of how much the inequality was, imagine that some houses had a toilet built especially for maids. Whites couldn't stand sharing the same bathroom with blacks because blacks were thought to be of another nature, of another social stratum, and might have some incurable diseases. Minny, one of the maids, was fired for using guests bathroom. By and large, maids significantly affected the day-to-day well-being of the hosts of the houses. They knew how to cook tasty and diverse food, how to clean house, and, I'd like to draw your attention to that, they knew how to raise children. The last picture of the film shows us how much a kid got attached to the help. Unfortunately, white hosts could not put their pride aside in some situations and, regardless of how much their child loved Aibileen, the help, they fired her. What surprised me is that blacks were afraid to talk about their deprivations to anyone, they were threatened by being exposed and were inclined to keep all their lives secret from the general public. It was extremely complicated to Skeeter, the young journalist, to make them believe that her intentions are pure and she just wants to write a book about maid's lives. Luckily, Skeeter sought a way how to deal with the problem and finally established enough credibility with a number of maids and the book has been published. So, we could watch such an incredible film.

Review: A movie from the point of view of the help a movie that deserves a nod at the Oscars! Title: THE HELP
Review_Url: Although Kathryn Stockett struggled with over 60 agents and had her novel rejected repeatedly the 2011 summer release THE HELP is been widely accepted even as you read this. Summer 2011 is not one of the best we have experienced in the lines of cinema. With just a handful of movies that would remain in our minds I consider THE HELP an exhilarating and heartwarming production that contains emotions and laughter from a time not too long ago. I have not clearly lived during the timelines the plot has been set. In fact the Civil rights movements and the efforts to create equality between color, race and religion is something I have just read during history lessons. To see it been brought to life at a time where racism and religious discrimination is frowned upon and where equality is boasted of is quite interesting. Especially to read the uprising debates the movie seems to have caused within some communities. If THE HELP is fact or fiction is irrelevant at this point. However the beauty and the depth the movie is revealed to me should not go unnoticed. There is an aura of near perfection that seems to hover around this title. The screenplay that has been adapted by the novel itself is said to be doing extreme justice to the original text the experts say. I have not read the novel. In fact I have not read the Harry Potter novels. However this does not stop me nor did it stop those who passed judgment on the HP franchise. The magical screenplay and direction that is done by Tate Taylor who is said to be a childhood friend of the author is key ingredient. Taylor's vision and heart is in the right place when he tries to extract the emotional lives of the black women of Jackson Mississippi. I have read many write ups about the racial atrocities that has taken place around the world. In fact I have seen with my own eyes the ethnic conflicts that stir up from some of them. THE HELP is just one of those stories that made it to the light! Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer clearly stood out with one of the best performances I have seen in recent times. They drew tears to my eyes. To be the help at the said time and to be in their situation is something that I am unable to even imagine myself in. Yet Spencer and Davis took me to 1960s Jackson. They showed me the pain and discrimination. They showed how much they gave up just making sure their children could have a better life (Although the outcome was not what they expected). The most important lesson I learnt by being in the year 2011 from the movie is that even with all the imaginable hardships of the world are upon them, they will not give up! Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer you ladies nailed it! There convincing performance was not too far away from Bryce Dallas Howard who places the other extreme end of the racial white house lady. Her ultimate goal of creating equality from within separation, Brilliant performance! Tate Taylor wanted her to come out as being mean insensitive and callous and Bryce Howard did Taylors expectations Justice. Between the help and the lords of the house there is a common ground. This is where Emma Stone comes in. I need to be honest; I was not a believer that Stone could pull through the perfect Skeeter. To my amazement she did. This Performance of Stone holds the Davis-Spencer Vs Howard battle in a balance. Aibileen Clark who has raised 17 white children is a black woman from Jackson Mississippi. She loves the children she raises just as if they were her own. In fact the children love the help more than they love their own mothers. This is only fair since the mothers of the time showed seem to have got their priorities pretty mixed up! Minny Jackson who works for the Holbrook house walks out one day after failing to tolerate the cruelty of the lady of the house. Jackson Journal writer Skeeter returns home after her graduation to find out that her maid Constantine who has raised all her life has been sent away by her mother. Skeeter who does not respond to this very well takes up to write the stories of black women and their emotional struggle for survival. However she is unable to find a volunteer who would share with her. THE HELP is a must watch drama and is indeed one of a kind. Guaranteed to have you balling out by the end of the movie and will make you look harder into yourself. A movie from the point of view of the help a movie that deserves a nod at the Oscars! Title: THE HELP Directed by: Tate Taylor Starring: Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer and Bryce Dallas Howard Rated: PG13 for thematic material Rating: 09/10 146 Minutes

Review_Url: The help is a movie about a dark period in American history that is remarkably funny. I think it's refreshing because you can have different approaches to traumatic events. Actress Viola Davis has since distanced herself from the movie saying that it did not provide voices for the black characters in the film. It seems such an odd thing to say, and you wonder if she actually watched the movie. Because yes a white character is used as a sort of framing device - the movie is all about the lives of these women who have to live within the framework of this rich, white, very racist society. Maybe her criticism is because we do not see major events in the lives of the black characters in the film, we only hear about them, whereas we do see major events in the white characters lives. But I think instead of criticizing this film for what it is, why not make another film about the same character but focusing on those aspects of her life? For the first time in a major film, the focus is on how white women treated black women during the era of Jim Crow. Rather than another harrowing portrayal of the horrors of racism involving white men treating black men badly, very badly, we see something that is every bit as disturbing. White women, many of them, degrading and demeaning black women, many of them, in so many small and cruel ways that it makes you ashamed. Much of it is painful to watch, and it's mostly done with soul-killing looks and words, very ugly words. Review_Url: This is the first time in my life I have ever liked the movie version better than the book. I finished the book the night before seeing the movie. The book left a lot of unanswered story lines, and it also left Hilly on top, with no one really telling her what a piece of trash she really is. The film does an excellent job of incorporating a majority of the book, while adding two scenes where Hilly finally has someone tell her what an a$$hole she really is. I rank the movie a 9 out of 10 because it really is almost perfect. It has Emma Stone as Skeeter trying to break out as a writer by tackling the hot button topic of segregation from the view point of the help. Both supporting characters-Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer-carry the wisdom and truly make you question how racist morons in the south as high up as the governor were able to reign supreme for so long. Skeeter's mother-Allison Janney-lit up the screen. She is the souther belle that has also been dealt a pretty harsh case of cancer that has left her losing her hair and her speed, but she still pushes for the best for her little girl, and in the end proves to be proud of her daughter for being such a courageous writer and human being. Now we have Hilly Holbrook-Bryce Dallas Howard-the villain of the film. I LOVED her in this role. The very sight of her on screen turned my stomach every time. She is a self proclaimed Christian southern belle, but is in reality an ignorant racist that enjoys controlling all her friends and pretty much everything in her life and everyone else's life. She enjoys treating the help terribly, it appears to genuinely make her happy. This is where the book failed terribly. The book had Hilly come out on top, with no one ever really giving it to her. The movie is redeeming, and I cried numerous times throughout. I see numerous Oscar nominations in its future.

Review_Url: Down here in Brazil, we -- or at least I -- had the impression that this movie was going to make some subtle observations as to the employer/domestic relationship. It was looked forward to as a contribution to comparative ethnography. What a surprise! The movie was neither dramatic enough to be a drama nor comic enough to be a comedy. Pity Divine from the old John Waters movies wasn't still alive to do the part of Hilly. At the conclusion of "Pink Flamingos" many decades ago, Divine did a memorable star turn with dirt the dog had left behind, so Divine might have brought some dimension and resonance to the heavy-handed scene in which Hilly eats chocolate cake, whereas the performance by the little Hollywood actress, whoever she is, had barely enough richness for a remake of National Lampoon's Dorm Daze. Audiences aren't resentful of being hammered with the obvious seven times over? E.g., that Aibeleen, not the white woman, is the standard-issue cute toddler's only real mother? As for the repeated returns to the face of the wounded child in the window, shameless, shameless, shameless. Anyone with a serious interest in employer/domestic relations -- and not merely in smugly being on the right side of a battle that, at least in the terms stated, was won a long time ago -- would do well to get hold of the Brazilian film Domésticas, which I believe is in video stores in the U.S. under the title Maids.

Author: 27 May 2012
Review: A celebration! A miracle that is both entertaining and lyrical.
Review_Url: Whatever happened to the old-fashioned films that didn't need special effects, talking animals or huge action scenes? Relax, here's one to help you calm your nerves. The movie "The Help", based on the best-selling novel (that me and my mom read) by Kathryn Stockett, is just as lyrical and enjoyable as the book itself. Being a movie that is 146 minutes long, you have to give credit to Tate Taylor, who is not only the screenwriter and director of the film, but is also Stockett's childhood friend who definitely promised to stay true to her book without falling apart. Set in the segregated, 1960's Jackson, Mississippi, the story follows three women: 2 African-American maids, Aibileen (Viola Davis) and Minny (Octavia Spencer, in her breakout, Oscar-winning performance) and Skeeter (Emma Stone from "Easy A"), a white college-grad who wants to be a writer, but ends up writing a cleaning column for the local newspaper. Aibileen hasn't seen much hope in her life after her son, Treelore passed away years ago. She's basically tired of working for white women who are basically racist toward the maids and don't like raising their own children. All she wants is for her stories to be told. This comes into the point of Skeeter, who had a maid, Constantine (Cicely Tyson), who disappeared years ago. She also has to have a controlling mother (Allison Janney) and doesn't want to be controlled by her or her friend Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard), who, along with her friends in the Junior League, happens to be racist as well. Skeeter comes up with an idea to write a book about what it's like for a African-American woman working as a maid. When Aibileen and Minny join this "secret" project, this proves to be a great idea by changing and breaking the rules and the society in which they lived by, angering Hilly and surprising everybody in this small Southern town. "The Help" is NOT a chick flick, to be clear. This is a movie for everybody and it is a movie that a mother and her son can enjoy together (I should know because me and my mom loved it). It has great characters, a warm heart, and something for us to believe in: Hope. I was definitely anticipated to see this movie right after I read the book and I had no idea that this movie would actually become a big hit. Now we know. The all-star cast is electrifying. Emma Stone is amazing as Skeeter. The character Hilly in the book is more of a snobby Southern diva who wants just segregation and how everything should be done her way. Bryce Dallas Howard does play it, but adds a few sides of her to show that there are some good things about her. (I basically loved her and her comeuppances). Jessica Chastain is perfect as Celia Foote, a Southern belle who is basically being shunned by Hilly and her group, but finds a friend in Minny. Now for the scene-stealers: Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer. They are excellent when you see them. Davis captures her shining moment yet in her first leading role, bringing light and hope for Aibileen. Spencer is hilarious and warmhearted as Minny, who has some secrets that has to be kept somewhere secret. If there was a movie that has to be talked about other than "The Hunger Games", I choose this one because it is funny, sweet and it feels so authentic to the period and you want to be cheering for the three women for making a change and finding courage in their lives. I think this movie itself is a dream come true for anyone hoping to tell their stories. What a miraculous movie. What a celebration.

Does not look like a girl of the period. Minor maybe, rest of period seems pretty well depicted ... unless I missed something else. Not a great film, but a flawed film with great performances worth seeing.

Review: "The Help" is one for the Ages
Review_Url: I enjoyed the movie because it followed a logical sequence that captured the genuine vernacular of the period. The attitudes of the characters in the movie are not fictitious; they represent the real attitudes of an oppressing group. The condescending stereotypes and attitudes did not die with the end of the era, some of the accompanying lifestyles did. Some of the families who employed house cleaners and other domestic help were not rich or even middle class people. They under paid their help with sub-minimum wages and expected much more return than investment. They enjoyed a luxurious lifestyle at the expense of the black domestic workers who served for little pay. The most important aspect of "The Help" is the moral implications of how domestic workers affected the lives of the children they raised, befriended, and loved. Despite the mistreatment they often endured, many of the workers attached themselves emotionally and the families rarely reciprocated. Some of the young children identified with the domestic service providers more than they could relate to their own biological parents. The maids often instilled a strong sense of self-esteem and a proud, but healthy, confidence into the children they raised for white people while they struggled to do the same at home. The dichotomy between their surrogate roles within white homes and their reality often produced major psychological torture and emotional turmoil. The same superior attitude that demands special privilege and entitlement prevails today, but the issue is no longer just black and white nor is it confined to the South. "The Help" dares to scratch the surface that illustrates a mild realization of the actual degradation imposed upon an innocent cross section of American society. I highly recommend this movie to every American who likes history, especially in light of our society's preoccupation and fascination with many aspects of the lifestyles of the rich and famous. This movie will serve as moral tonic and a dose of reality for families and school aged children old enough to understand.

How shocking, how risquéwait it is 2011, right? Are there such things as artistic boundaries anymore? Maybe for Taylor, whose film version of his friend's runaway hit novel, is stealing the hearts of America right before our eyes. And maybe he played it a bit safe, but it's a rare safeness that is hardly ever done well. Lucky, again, for Mr. Taylor, his result is amazing.

So we know it's fictional and nothing has changed. The story is of an aspiring newspaper reporter come writer returning from New York to Jackson and see's the opportunity to write a book on 'The Help' the black maids who raised the white children of the south but were unable to look after their own or indeed use the toilet facilities within the house. There is no doubt this is a well told story and to not be moved would possibly put you amongst the red necks. Their were some very funny moments and the screenplay by Tate Taylor has picked up the essence of the ongoing attitudes. If there is one thing I would like to see is a redistribution of the wealth of this film/book to the people of this story and a fitting memorial in Jackson for the people to reflect on their attitudes.

Review_Url: Based on the book by Kathryn Stockett, The Help takes place in the deep south (Mississippi) in the early 1960's. A well-educated, White college graduate, Eugenia aka Skeeter, (Emma Stone) comes home from college to find her beloved "maid, or nanny," Constantine is nowhere to be found. She comes home with a new perspective of her other high-class socialite friends and family, and begins to take notice of how "the help" or the African American maids are treated. After getting a job at the local newspaper, Skeeter decides to write an article that is in the point of view of "the help," that becomes a book and turns the whole town into a frenzy. Although Skeeter is technically the "main character," the maids (Led by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer) are what make this movie magical. Their portrayals are intimate, and emotional. Their stories are touching, beautiful, sorrowful yet so profound. The picture painted of the South is not a pretty one, when integration was a new concept, and the lines drawn between whites and blacks were thick. When ignorance was at its peak, and hatred was hiding behind every corner. Still, somehow, these beautiful African American women had hope for a change & for a better future, and courage enough to make a difference.

Review: Wonderful portrayal of complicated intercations reflecting the complications of real life situations.
Review_Url: I recommend this movie. The story, the production, the casting and the film techniques are wonderful. The story is easy to follow and entertaining and at the same time it presents a portray of real life that is full of complications. A young women writer approaches the difficult task of presenting the lives of the "help" in a southern town from the perspective of "the help." A group of rich ladies who like and dislike each other are presented as real life persons who need to carry out expected roles with aggravation, with respect and with lack of respect in their interactions with the help. You feel like you were there seeing the story develop but at the same time the movie allows you to be critical of the reality of the time. The southern ladies are portrayed in a manner that shows their pros and cons. They are the well dressed, dedicated wives who have to have a perfect home and at the same time they are the daughters and wives of less than perfect family members. The maids are hard working, dedicated, and they love the children they care for but at the same time they feel trapped and it is hard for them to be loyal to their bosses. The movie manages to show several sides of the same story with a nicely flowing rhythm that is captivating and does not allow the viewer a brake. You are in the movie for a whole two hours.

There are moments in the movie when you will cry and there are moments when you will laugh and isn't that what storytelling is all about. The movie is about how the African American maids were treated during the time of the civil rights movement But the movie has so many layers that it hits at so many levels. Most of the stories in the movie are about how there existed discrimination during that time and how the African American COLORED maids were treated by the families they worked for but it also gives beautiful examples of some employers being good to their maids and a different kind of discrimination which exists for a girl who has just gotten married rich and is considered WHITE TRASH. So you see discrimination in so many forms: discrimination because of skin color, discrimination because of wealth and other forms. The relationship these maids have with the children that aren't theirs is also beautiful. There are so many scenes that move the viewer especially the one in which Constantine is fired and Cicely Tyson is just so fine in the scene where she makes an impact without even opening her mouth with no lines at all. This one is sure going to my favorites list. Please don't miss it. It would touch you at so many levels that you would feel that why you hadn't seen it earlier.

What I also liked about the movie, was that you learn you have to stand up for those who don't have a voice, and how important it is to make a difference, no matter how small or big. What I missed was that some of Skeeter white friends should have stand up and join her in some way. There's much portrayal of what is fair and about consequences. I wished Skeeter's mom would have had a bigger development during the movie. We see that she's all about other opinions about her, and I wished she just gave that up and supported Skeeter in the end. Review: After aspiring writer, Skeeter, returns home from college, she interviews African American women who work as "the help" to find out what their treatment was really like.
Review_Url: After some resistance, Skeeter is able to record the testimonies of several African American women who work as "the help" for white, Southern families. They reveal how they are treated as well as the secrets of the families they work for. This film in set in the 1960's Civil Rights era. It is two-sided in that it shows there were white families and people that were in favor for equal treatment of African Americans. The film is able to convey messages of equality in an uplifting tone through use of comic relief. The scenery of Mississippi provides beautiful views throughout the film. Emma Stone is a fun character and seems really genuine with the interviewees. Viola Davis (who plays Abileine, a maid) is an amazing actor making the film more realistic. In summary, I would recommend this film to those who are interested in historical films as well as people who enjoy Emma Stone as an actor.

Author: 15 April 2015
Review_Url: The Help is an amazing movie. It incorporates relationship struggles, historical events, and funny comedy all into one, two hour movie. I have now watched this movie two times and have decided there are two ways to watch the film. One way is you can watch the film by seeing it as a cute story about black and whites becoming friends during a time of inequality and oppression. There are plenty laughable parts of the movie making it light hearted and a feel good movie for the weekend. Another way to watch the movie is by looking at the more complex issues of the movie. This movie is set during a time when there was not equality. Not only were black people oppressed, but so were women. This movie focuses on both black and white women and the struggles they faced living in a society dominated by white males. The fear, hopelessness, and courage shown in this movie illustrates the times of the Civil Rights movement when so many black people were afraid yet felt the need to fight for a better future. There are plenty complex issues of feminism, racial injustice, and relationship struggles introduced in this movie making it very meaningful. However, the comedy, amazing acting, and outrageous characters makes this a movie accessible and enjoyable even to those of us who are not history buffs. I would recommend watching this movie!

Author: 17 April 2015
Review_Url: This was a wonderful and moving film. Throughout the duration of the movie, I laughed, I cried, I clapped, I cringed with discomfort and squirmed with anticipation. The range of emotions I experienced can be credited to not only the excellence of the story writing but the quality of the acting and the personality of the actors chosen to portray each role. I especially appreciated that the focus was to develop the characters of the maids as opposed to the white ladies that they worked for. This allows for a consistency between the main character's goal to write from the Negro perspective and the goal of the film itself. Unfortunately, it seems that some critics think that this film and storyline are not realistic. It has been criticized for simplifying the complex race relations and omitting the various forms of violence that characterize the time period.

Author: 14 April 2015
Review_Url: The help is a film full of emotion, and hope, telling the story of the black housemaids in southern Mississippi and their relationships with their white employers. A college graduate of Ole Miss, aspiring journalist and society woman of Mississippi, Skeeter Phalen, goes to work on a piece that evolves into a sort of exposé on the help and their relationships and feelings toward their white counterparts. Throughout the movie you are taken on a journey of highs, and lows, that is very emotion evoking. Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson are the two main maids that Skeeter gets her information and stories from, however once they start talking, many more women tell their stories as well. There is a background element of the secret that Skeeters mother is keeping about the mysterious disappearance of Skeeter's family's own housemaid which is just another one of many elements that keep you wrapped around the story and wanting more. The whole story serves as a kind of hopeful element of this time, among the tragedy that is touched on throughout the movie, it doesn't seem to focus so much highlighting the very terrible ways that whites treated their black slaves in this time, but rather on the fact that through the use of Skeete and her sympathy and interest toward the help that not all white people were terrible people back then, which serves as the element of hope for society throughout the movie. Overall I was very impressed with this film and would definitely recommend it to anyone who is interested in historical happenings of this nature, or are just in the mood for a heartwarming story.

Add the book to your summer reading list along with 'Murder Behind Closed Doors,' by Jere Myles, a similar story about characters who refuse to be invisible in a society that would be more comfortable if they were. It's a simple story, set in Jackson, Mississippi, during the early 60s. You don't need a history lesson about what's going on, but it's an education for those who've never heard the word colored used to refer to anyone who was not white. I grew up in Tennessee, and it was like a walk home, and when Aibilene tells Skeeter, who wants to write about the help, she'd never had a white person in her house, it was like "I can't either." Ironically, the movie for me was somewhat reminiscent of Whoopi Goldberg's "The Long Walk Home."

Review: Lighter Fare than the Book, But Still Remarkable
Review_Url: For those of you who read the book, you may as I did often compare the differences within the movie. However, I still truly appreciated the performances, the funny moments and certainly the heartfelt moments that elicited some of my tears. The two biggest differences between the book and movie were the tone and lack of character depth, save the characters of Aibeleen and Minny. Although Skeeter was lovable, Celia cute and Stuart, well, he just made a couple of short appearances, none were captured in a way that truly showed the core of who they were nor explained their treatment of others within the story. *SPOILER* In the movie you see Minny showing Celia how to cook fried chicken, however in the book, their cooking lessons took place every day and cemented their bonding and friendship. As well, the side story in the book where Celia literally saves Minny's life is completely left out of the movie. All in all, the movie was a beautiful story filled with laughs and extraordinary performance by the lovely ladies who played Aibeleen, Minny, Hilly and Celia. I would recommend seeing this to anyone with sensitive sensibilities. Although there were a few men in the full theatre I was in, I am hesitant to say that "even your guy" will love it. So, men be warned that this may be your idea of a "chick flick", or perhaps shame on me, this may just be a movie for everyone.

Review_Url: The Help is smart, witty, scandalous and a tear-jerker all in one. Tate Taylor took a risky chance writing a movie that brought us back to a dark period in American history due to racism an inequality. He did a very good job creating the experience of the movie to be surprisingly light- hearted and touching. With help from leading actresses Viola Davis, Emma Stone, and Allison Janney; these women did an incredible job making the Mississippi, Southern style of life come alive. The movie explains the relationships between African American maids during the 1960s and their families they provided for. With constant care taking, daily routines and chores many of the maids went about their lives saying very few words to the white folks. When Miss Skeeter Phelan, a University grad with a passion for writing, comes back to town, she stirs up a hot pot of drama. Persuading the maids to tell-all about their unspoken stories and redemption towards white families they have worked for, may have sounded like a good idea at the time. Lets just say that some thoughts are better off not spoken. The passion and friendship Skeeter shows towards these women is truly touching and heart-warming. This movie shows how the determination of one person can change the lives of many. At some point everyone is forced to make the choice of either staying with or breaking the status quo. The light humor and strong Southern accents will definitely keep you intrigued throughout the entire movie. The Help is a must see.

Review: Leaves all that watch a sense of urgency to stand up for what they believe in
Review_Url: The Help, based off of the 2009 novel by Kathryn Stockett, tells a story of three courageous women who join together to uncover ways they are mistreated as African American housemaids in the 1960's. Taking place in Jackson, Mississippi, these types of actions were unheard of. If caught, the members of "the help" would face arrest, never be able to find work again, and be shun from the city, however this did not stop them telling their story. Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan, played by Emma Stone, has just graduated from college and come back to her hometown. After scoring her first job as a cleaning advice columnist which she is clueless about, she turns to Aibileen (Viola Davis) who is the African American housemaid of an old old childhood friend. to ask for advice. In doing so, she begins to notice how poorly Aibileen and other members of the help are treated, inspiring her to write a novel though the eyes of the help. Skeeter knows the dangers this can cause for Aibileen, ignores the consequences. After much convincing, Aibileen agrees to help, eventually recruiting her best friend Minny (Octivia Spencer) and other maids to join in the fight against the cities unjust treatment of the help. The writing of this book soon becomes much more than any of the women involve could have imagined, giving each of the maids a voice as well as a chance to finally tell the world what was seldom spoken of. It transforms into an important movement that was able to change the entire city of Jackson, Mississippi and the lives of all housemaids around the state.

Author: 24 September 2014
Review: The outstanding cast and engaging emotions, make The Help a must see.
Review_Url: People want to believe that they have courage, but they are unwilling to speak against social norms for fear of rejection. In The Help, Skeeter, an ambitious, white writer tries to explain what it is like for black women to serve white families during the civil rights era. Due to the social separation between the two races, she faces many obstacles in an attempt to compile stories from maids, such as Aibileen and Minny. The film does a great job of explaining the social differences at the time, while still giving the audience a deeper meaning to consider. The dialogue creates distinctions between the white and black characters through a difference in education. Although all of the characters talk with a slight southern accent, the white characters speak with sophisticated vocabulary, while the African American characters sound uneducated. The quote, "you is smart, you is kind, you is important," said by Aibileen, shows the limited education available for African Americans at the time. The way the different races talk about one another also indicates this separation. Hilly, a white housewife, insists on the necessity of separate bathrooms in houses due to the risk of catching "black diseases." The filmmakers make a point to show the different distinctions, giving the audience a better understanding of the social norms at the time. Through the use of heavy subject matter and humor, the filmmakers grab the audience's attention in an engaging way. The cruel accusations towards the maids, and brutality displayed by the white police officers, keep the film impactful, but the filmmakers incorporate humor to lift up the film's serious tone. Minny brings the humor to the film in her sassy comments. Humor is present when Minny tells Skeeter "You ain't got nothing left here but enemies in the Junior League. You done burned every bridge there is. And you ain't never gonna get another man in this town, everybody know that. So don't walk your white butt to New York, run it!" The filmmakers set the tone through serious events, but develop a more unpredictable plot by including humor. The unpredictability adds to the film's overall enjoyable story. Through the acting of Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer, the audience can better understand the characters they play. Viola Davis successfully portrays her character, Aibileen Clark, as a loving, hardworking individual. Davis delivers her lines with a tired voice, suggesting that she commits herself to her job. We also get the idea that her character is good with kids by the way she lights up around her boss' child, Mae Mobley. Davis is able to change her delivery to fit the scene. Octavia Spencer entertains the audience with her sassy interpretation of Minny Jackson. Spencer does this through mannerisms, such as pursing her lips, standing with her hands on her hip, and rolling her eyes. These mannerisms that Spencer uses add to the idea that her character is very head-strong. Octavia Spencer also delivers lines in a loud, bold manner. When Skeeter is interviewing Aibileen, Minnie storms into the scene and states, "And just what makes you think colored people need your help? Why you care?" Octavia does not hesitate before she delivers this line, adding to the confidence of her character. These actresses add believability to the film with their genuine portrayals of their roles. This film sets a precedent for future films discussing controversial topics such as the treatment of African Americans. This movie is not only entertaining, but it also sparks thought about how the audience treats others. It plays with the audience's emotions to ignite a passionate response to the subject of the movie.

Review_Url: The Help, before it was turned into a movie, was a great book. Though it painted the conditions of the South during this era in clean, easily digestible strokes, it told a great story of life in that situation.

Author: 3 April 2015
Review: A movie about the fight for equality and an end to African American discrimination through the eyes of a young white southern woman and two African American cleaning ladies.
Review_Url: The Help is an inspiring movie about African American discrimination and is based on the book by Kathryn Stockett. It goes through the lives of numerous people in Jackson, Mississippi. Although the transition from book to movie isn't perfect, the writers did a good job at including all the story lines and characters, showing the importance of each one no matter how little a role they had. A really emotional part was when Aibileen had to say goodbye to Mae Mobley at the end of the movie, knowing that she was the only good influence in the girl's life and that her mother wasn't able to take care of her the way she deserved. This scene was put together well and had just as much emotion in it as it did in the novel. The writers did a good job at showing the struggles Aibileen and Skeeter faced when trying to coordinate and get together to write the book about the poor conditions of "The Help" in white households. Overall, this movie is a good representation of what African Americans had to go through in the early to mid 1900s and I would recommend it to anyone.

Author: 12 April 2015
Review_Url: Over all the movie I thought had a touching message and was brilliantly acted by all the actors that portrayed these characters. As a movie based of a book I say that they followed the book pretty well. The reason this movie did not get a perfect 10 from me will be very apparent if you look at the historical inaccuracy of the book. Although the movie does portray a broad range on the 1960 from Jim Crow laws to the KKK and even Kennedy's assassination it down played the way living in Mississippi in the 1960's would have been like. Instead of showing the horrificness of killing, rape, abuse, lynching and racial slurs it was substituted by mean hose wife's who crated drama. Although maid at that time were a lot closer the the children then their own mothers were it doesn't excuse the fact of the movie tiptoeing around what it was actually like down south. Another thing that they hovered around was the maids telling the story knew and told of why it was dangerous but the sense of the physical danger they could face was missing. Overall it was a well casted movie and very touching storyline but not historically portrayed well.
